title: Ukiyo-e: Perspective View of Banquet in a Parlor at Ryō goku
transcript:
Narrator: Curator Janice Katz.

Janice Katz: So what we’re seeing here is a teahouse. It’s a place of assignation where clients could
make an appointment with a courtesan, and where they met the courtesans and were able to be
entertained by them.

It was seen as a mark of sophistication at this time if you were able to navigate this world. You had to be
somebody who understood the protocols, the manners, the timing. You had to have the money. You had
to deploy it at the right time in the right places. This was a very complex set of rituals to master.
Interestingly enough, there were a lot of guidebooks, printed guidebooks, novels that took place in the
Yoshiwara, and people just devoured these sources of information in order to learn more about the
pleasure quarters.

So a visit to the Yoshiwara was no doubt a lavish affair and it was made up of parading courtesans in
luxurious kimono, they had glittering hair ornaments, the whole experience was like a dream and this is
what is captured in the paintings.

However, the reality behind these depictions is that the women you see here, particularly the young girls
that you see in some of the paintings, they were sold into their contracts—indentured at a young age—by
impoverished families that must of felt that they had no other option, but it was a harsh life they were
entering.

High ranking courtesans were able to see fewer clients, but these brothels profited from these women you
were basically kept in perpetual debt for their expensive wardrobes, their living expenses, the living
expenses of their attendants…

And for those few that rose to the high ranks, they were educated, they contributed to the vibrant artistic
and culture life of the Yoshiwara, and their achievements are all the more incredible when you consider
the circumstances of their living a working conditions.
